sec.title: Abstract
sec.p:
The genus Amanita , comprising three subgenera and eleven sections, is one of the most species diverse genera within the class Agaricomycetes . To date, 54 species have been validly reported from Thailand . During surveys of macro-fungi in northern Thailand in 2019 and 2020, three Amanita species
were collected and identified as the members of Amanita sect. Lepidella based on morphological and molecular data. Among the three species, two species were identified as A. aureofloccosa and A. manicata and A. aureofloccosa is reported as a new record in Thailand . Interestingly, the third species was distinct from all other known species within sect. Lepidella . We describe the third species as a new species, namely A. albicarnosa . All these three taxa are documented with morphological characteristics, a phylogenetic tree, line drawings, color photographs, and comparisons with morphologically similar taxa. A distributional map of the sampling sites and a key to the Thai species of Amanita sect. Lepidella are also provided.
Key words: 1 new species, Amanitaceae , Phylogeny, Saprotrophic Amanita , Taxonomy, Tropical area

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Lepidella E.J. Gilb.
, was first described as a new genus to aggregate the Amanita species
having the strongly lepiotoid habit from Lepiota species
( Gilbert 1925 ). Shortly afterward, Beauseigneur (1926) listed his subgenus as “ Lepidella Gilbert
”. Veselý (1933) reduced Gilbert’s genus Lepidella to the subgeneric rank. However, the generic name Lepidella was subsequently proved to be illegitimate because it was a later homonym of Lepidella Tiegh.
( Loranthaceae ). Although Gilbert proposed a new generic name Aspidella E. J. Gilb. ( Gilbert 1940 )
to replace Lepidella , neither the former genus nor the latter genus have been generally accepted. With the exhaustive morphological study, Corner & Bas (1962) , and Bas (1969) sifted the generic classification of Amanita and divided it into two subgenera and six sections, of which the subgen. Lepidella (E. J. Gilb.) Veselý emend. Corner & Bas
includes four sections (sect. Amidella (E. J. Gilbert) Konrad & Maubl.
, sect. Lepidella Corner & Bas
, sect. Phalloideae (Fr.) Quél., and sect. Validae (Fr.) Quél.).
Redhead et al . (2016)
proposed a new generic name Saproamanita Redhead, Vizzini, Drehmel & Contu.
to replace both Lepidella and Aspidella . However, this propose was not or scarcely accepted by other mycologists (
Tulloss et al . 2016
;
Cui et al . 2018
;
Cui et al . 2021
,
Codjia et al . 2022
). Significantly, subgen. Lepidella became available after it was adapted to the subgeneric level. Based on multigene phylogenetic and morphological data,
Cui et al . (2018)
proposed to divide the genus Amanita into three subgenera and eleven sections (subgen. Amanita Pers.
, containing: sect. Amanita Pers.
, sect. Amarrendiae (Bougher & T. Lebel) Zhu L. Yang, Y.Y. Cui, Q . Cai & L.P. Tang, sect. Caesareae Singer ex Singer and sect. Vaginatae (Fr.) Quél
; subgen. Amanitina (E. J. Gilbert) E. J. Gilbert
, containing: sect. Amidella , sect. Arenariae Zhu L. Yang, Y.Y. Cui & Q . Cai, sect. Phalloideae , sect. Roanokenses Singer ex Singer, sect. Strobiliformes Singer ex Q . Cai, Zhu L. Yang & Y.Y. Cui and sect. Validae , and subgen. Lepidella Beauseigneur
, containing sect. Lepidella only).

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p: Morphological study

Basidiomata of the fresh specimens were collected from the rice stubble field, meadows or the deciduous forest in Chiang Rai and Chiang Mai provinces, Thailand . The morphological information such as location, forest type , substrate type , and field photographs were recorded. The fresh basidiomata were dried at 35–45°C at least for twelve hours ( Zhang & Yang 2004 ) and later deposited in the Herbarium of the Biology Department, Faculty of Science, Chiang Mai University (CMUB), Chiang Mai , Thailand .

Macroscopic characteristics were described based on field notes and digital images. Color codes and abbreviations were recorded according to Kornerup & Wanscher (1978) . Microscopic features were obtained from dried materials mounted in 5% aqueous KOH (w/v), 1% Congo red (w/v) and Melzer’s reagent under a Leica DM500 microscope. For the description of basidiospores, the notation [n/m/p] refers to n basidiospores were measured from m basidiomata of p collections. Dimensions for basidiospores are given as (a–) b–c (–d) in which ‘b–c’ represents a minimum of 90% of the measured and extreme values and ‘a’ and ‘d’ are given in parentheses whenever necessary. Q denotes the ratio of length divided by the width of the basidiospore in the side view, Qm denotes the average Q of n measured basidiospores and SD is their standard deviation. Results are presented as Q = Qm ± SD. Marginal striations on the pileus are expressed as a proportion of the ratio of striation length to the radius of the pileus (nR). The terms referring to the size of basidiomata and spores shape are adopted according to the definitions of Bas (1969) and Yang (2015) .

sec.title: DNA extraction, PCR amplification and sequencing
sec.p:
Methods of DNA extraction and PCR amplification were followed on the basis of
Cai et al . (2016)
and
Liu et al . (2021)
. Five DNA gene fragments were sequenced, including the internal transcribed spacer region (ITS), the large subunit of the nuclear ribosomal DNA (nrLSU), the partial sequences of the RNA polymerase II second largest subunit ( RPB2 ), translation elongation factor 1-alpha ( TEF 1-α
) and beta-tubulin gene ( TUB ). Sequences generated in this study were subjected to BLASTn (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov) analysis and submitted to GenBank.

sec.title: Phylogenetic analyses
sec.p:
Detailed information about sequences retrieved from GenBank and the sequences newly generated in this study were provided in Table 1 . Phylogenetic analysis was carried out based on only the nrLSU and ITS sequences because the amount of available sequence data in the RPB2 , TEF 1-α
, and TUB genes for the selected species are practically limited. Sequences for each single gene were separately aligned with MAFFT v.7 ( Katoh & Standley 2013 ) using the G-INSi iterative refinement algorithm, and then checked visually and manually optimized using AliView v.1.28 ( Larsson 2014 ). Gblocks v. 0.91b ( Castresana 2000 ) was used to check and exclude the ambiguously aligned regions for ITS, selecting two options “Allow smaller final blocks” and “Allow gap positions within the final blocks”. Sequence Matrix v.100.0 was applied to combine the two gene fragments for further phylogenetic analysis. The best-fit model of nucleotide substitution was determined for each single gene dataset by using MrModeltest v. 2.3 ( Nylander 2004 ) following the default parameters. Phylogenetic tree inference was performed using both Bayesian inference (BI) and maximum likelihood (ML), as detailed in
Dissanayake et al . (2020)
.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Sample collection and morphological observation

A total of ten specimens of Amanita subgen. Lepidella were obtained from northern Thailand (
). Morphologically, three specimens (SDBR-STO-2020-PS38, SDBR-STO-2020-PS39 & SDBR-CMUNK1470) and four specimens (SDBR-STO-2019-347, SDBR-STO-2019-390, SDBR-STO-2020-34 & SDBR-STO-2020-36) shared the same morphological characteristics with A. aureofloccosa and A. manicata , respectively. However, the morphological characteristics of the other three saprobic specimens (CMUB-39971, SDBR-STO-2020-01 & SDBR-STO-2020-04) differed from any other previously known species in Amanita subgen. Lepidella . These three specimens probably represent a potential new species. Therefore, the identification of all these specimens was then further confirmed by phylogenetic analyses.

sec.title: Phylogenetic analyses
sec.p:
Our optimized two-gene tree showed similar phylogenetic positions with the single-gene tree. The putative new species clustered together with Amanita inopinata D. A . Reid & Bas ( Reid 1987 ), A. pruittiiA . H. Sm. ex Tulloss, J . Lindgr. & Arora (
Tulloss et al . 2014
), A. quitensis E. Caicedo
, A . Barili, C.W. Barnes & Ordoñez (
Crous et al . 2018
), and A. singer Bas ( Bas 1969 )
, and all these species formed a monophyletic clade with the high support (BS = 100% and PP = 1.0). Moreover, three collections representing A. albicarnosa presented as a well-supported distinct lineage (BS = 100% and PP = 1.0) which can be identified as a distinct species. The collections of SDBR-STO-2020-PS38 and SDBR-STO-2020-PS39 clustered together with A. aureofloccosa present as a well-supported distinct lineage (BS = 100% and PP = 1.0) which can be identified as a new record of A. aureofloccosa . Five collections of A. manicata from Thailand and other two samples from America and New Zealand formed a monophyletic lineage.

Remarks: Morphologically, Amanita aureofloccosa is unique among congeners by having a pulverulent, bright orange-yellow volva remnant on its pileus, a slender stipe covered by orange-yellow floccose scales, a globose to subglobose, amyloid basidiospore and the lacking clamps in all parts of basidiomata. According to the original literature ( Bas 1969 ), the basidiospores size of A. aureofloccosa was described as 7–8.5 × 6.5–8.5 μm, but Wartcow et al . (2015) re-examined the lectotype (BR2229) and additional material from Ghana (K173243), and amended the basidiospores size to (6.5–) 6.8–10.5 (–10.8) × (6.5–) 6.8–10.2 (–10.5) μm, of which the results are similar to Thai material. Significantly, compared to the materials from other countries, our collections from Thailand have larger basidiomata and basidia.
Habitat: Solitary to scattered in black sand at berm of beach, on soil in grass or forest, in composted woodchips, April to October.
Distribution: Known from Dominican Republic , New Zealand , Sri Lanka , Thailand , and the USA (Hawaiian Islands) ( Petch 1910 ; Pegler 1986 ; Hemmes & Desjardin 2008 ).

Remarks: Amanita manicata is characterized by its yellowish brown to pale tawny brown pileus covering with floccoso-verrucose to felty squamules; margin appendiculates with large floccose fragments which hang down up to 2 cm ; the cylindrical stipe covering with tawny brown floccoso-squamose which becomes more intense and thicker as upwards; the cream to whitish or pinkish tint lamellae; the subglobose and amyloid basidiospores (7.0–8.5 × 5.5–8.0 μm), as well as the present clamps. In our phylogenetic analysis, A. manicata closed to A. flavofloccosa Nagas. & Hongo
, A. foetidissima Reid & Eicker
and A. nauseosa (Wakef.) Reid
and they formed a sister group (
). Meanwhile, these four species share the similar appearance and color tone of basidioma, as well as the intense and unpleasant odor, which make people easily confuse for these species in the field. However, A. flavofloccosa can be distinguished from A. manicata by its yellow-brown to orange-yellow pileus and white, pinkish to yellowish lamellae (
Cui et al . 2018
). Amanita foetidissima , originally reported from South Africa ( Reid & Eicker 1991 ), has a pale creamy buff to buff pileus, oval to subglobose (7.0–9.0 × 6.2–8.0 μm), to broadly ellipsoid (9.0–10.0 × 6.0–6.2 μm) basidiospores, as well as the larger basidia (50.0–52.0 × 9.0–9.5 μm). Although A. nauseosa is very similar to A. manicata , it has a buff, or reddish-tinged to pale ochraceous buff surface and the greater basidiospores (7.0–9.0 × 6.5–8.0 μm) ( Bas 1969 ).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
According to Bas (1969) , subsect. Vittadiniae comprises five stirps (stirps Hesleri , stirps Nana , stirps Nauseosa , stirps Thiersii and stirps Vittadinii ).
Cui et al . (2018)
assigned stirps Hesleri and the rest four stirps to A .
subgen. Amanitina sect. Phalloideae and A .
subgen. Lepidella sect. Lepidella , respectively. In Bas’s monograph, species in stirps Thiersii can be firstly recognized on account of the absent clamp. Then species in stirps Nauseosa are characterized by their globose to broadly ellipsoid spores and lanose-floccose to floccose-squamulose and medially concentrated volval remnants on the stipe ( Bas 1969 ). Species in stirps Nana and stirps Vittadinii are characterized by having broadly ellipsoid to elongate spores and scattered or more rarely indistinct volval remnants on the stipe. Following above morphological characteristics, the novel species A. albicarnosa assigns to stirps Vittadinii , A. aureofloccosa and A. manicata separately match with stirps Thiersii and stirps Nauseosa . Meanwhile, our phylogenetic analysis almost entirely repeated Bas’s division in subsect. Vittadiniae . Our nrLSU-ITS phylogenetic analysis showed that there are five clades in subgen. Lepidella (
). The known species, A. manicata and our Thai new record, A. aureofloccosa were assigned to clade I and clade III, respectively. Clade II contains three species, namely A. silvifuga , A . prairiocola and A. pleropus . Clade II contains A. codinae and A . vittadinii (the type species of subgen. Lpidella and sect. Lepidella ). The new species A. albicarnosa , coupling with A. singeri , A. pruittii , A. quitensis , and A. inopinata formed the basal taxa with well support values (clade V).

Summarizing, five clades in our phylogenetic analyses could respectively correspond with three stirps (stirps Nauseosa , stirps Thiersii and stirps Vittadinii ) in Bas’s division. Under this relationship, clade II, clade IV and clade V well matched with stirps Vittadinii . Clade I and clade III well accorded with stirps Nauseosa and stirps Thiersii , respectively. It should be noted that the position of clade IV was not fixed probably because of the limited sequences. The distinct morphological differences and phylogenetic relationship indicate that Amanita subgen. Lepidella which contains a single section could be split into three or more sections.
